<u>Disposition of the basal ganglia in relation to 
the capsules <\u> Nearly opposite the anterior extremity 
of the Island of Reil the <u>tractus externus <\u> splits 
into two sets of fibres. The inner mass is the 
denser & thicker of the two, & consists of bundles 
running obliquely backwards. It is the 
<u>inner capsule <\u>. The remainder of the <u>tractus
externus <\u> is composed of a band of fibres running 
backwards & downwards, and outside of, but in contact with it 
are certain interconvolutional fibres wh: are 
now connected with the Island of Reil (Fig 3 f.f.)
The splitting of the <u>tractus externus <\u> is brought 
about by the interposition of a mass of grey 
matter flat on the inside & convex <s>on the 
outside <\s> externally (Fig 4). This grey mass is the first appearance of the <u>nucleus lenticularis <\u>. A
short way further back the remainder of the 
<u>tractus externus <\u> is separated from the interconvolutional 
fibres of the Island by a thin strip of grey matter.
This grey matter is the claustrum, & the <u>tractus 
externus <\u> being thus separated by it <s>from the interconvol-
utional fibres of the Island <\s> becomes the <u>outer 
capsule <\u>; while the interconvolutional fibres a 
little further back are transformed into the 
“white substance of the Island of Reil “. (Fig 4)
